p.i: The House met at Half-past Two o'Clock

publicwhip.major-heading: PRAYERS

speech.p: [Mr. SPEAKER in the Chair]

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — ROADS

speech.p: asked the Minister of Transport if he has any statement to make in connection with the alteration of the speed limit for goods vehicles from 20 m.p.h. to 30 m.p.h. for heavy goods vehicles on pneumatic tyres.
I would refer the hon. Member to the answer I gave on 1st November to a Question by the hon. Member for Buckrose (Mr. Wadsworth), of which I am sending him a copy.

asked the Minister of Transport whether he will consider publishing simple instructions clarifying the existing law regarding priority of usage between pedestrians and motor traffic at studded street crossings.

The provisions of the Pedestrian Crossing Places (Traffic) Regulations, 1941, are clearly summarised on page 28 of the Highway Code. I have asked the Committee on Road Safety to examine the question of the use and observance of pedestrian crossing places, and when they have reported I will consider whether the regulations can be improved.

Would the right hon. Gentleman bear in mind that the present position is quite chaotic, that the issue is constantly between weight and agility, that the odds are, generally, on weight—that is, on the motor vehicle—and that the pedestrian has to suffer?
I would not agree that the conditions are chaotic. It is laid down quite clearly in the orders issued that the pedestrian has the right of way with regard to pedestrian crossings.
The pedestrian may have the right of way, but if the motor vehicle persists in going on, he has to be very quick to get out of its way.
I would point out that a fine is imposed if the conditions are infringed.
Would my right hon. Friend commend to other areas the very excellent arrangements which exist in Kensington High Street? They are first-class in that part of London.
The rules and regulations are no different in Kensington High Street from elsewhere.
Can the Minister tell us whether, where there are lights on the crossings, the pedestrian has the right to pass whether those lights are green or red?
No, Sir, the pedestrian has not that right when the lights are against him.

asked the Minister of Transport whether he will authorise the reinstatement of the traffic control signals at the junction of Lough-borough Road, Angell Road and Brixton Road, which have not been operating since the war.
The reinstatement of these signals has already been agreed upon, and I understand that the local authority have ordered the necessary equipment.
Is my right hon. Friend aware that this agreement will be very welcome to the many pedestrians who have to use this crossing?

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — TRANSPORT CONSULTATIVE COMMITTEES

speech.p: asked the Minister of Transport what progress is being made in regard to the setting up of the Consultative Committees provided for under the Transport Act.

I have now received nominations from the representative bodies which I have consulted in connection with the establishment of the Central Transport Consultative Committee. I expect to be in a position in the very near future to announce the setting up of the Central Committee and also the names of the chairmen of the committees for Scotland and Wales.

Will my right hon. Friend speed up the appointment of these Committees in view of the fact that the British Transport Commission are already engaged in large schemes of reorganisation, and that the Consultative Committees ought to have a say in such reorganisation?
The important thing, of course, is to get the right people.

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — MINISTRY OF SUPPLY

speech.p: asked the Minister of Supply whether he will now discontinue the sale by auction of surplus machine tools which would be required for essential production in the event of the outbreak of war.

speech.speakername: The Minister of Supply (Mr. G. R. Strauss)
speech.p: No machine tool is sold if it is required as a reserve or for other Government purposes.

Did the Minister read the article in the "Daily Graphic" of last Saturday which was headed "Our War Tools for the Iron Curtain"; and further, is there any restriction on the export of machine tools bought by auction?
Yes, Sir, they are all subject to restriction and come under a Board of Trade order.
Is the Minister aware that a number of machine tools are finding their way to Palestine by similar devious channels?
Will the Minister undertake that none of these machine tools will be sent to Russia?
I have said that no machine tools required in this country for reserve, and, indeed, none required for making munitions, are exported.

asked the Minister of Supply whether he is aware that 36,000 pieces of radio equipment dumped by his Department in a disused pit shaft at Cheadle, Staffs, and declared in the House of Commons by his predecessor on 17th December, 1945, to be valueless, have now been recovered after the shifting and replacing of 200 tons of dirt and disposed of by private enterprise at a profit; and whether he will investigate the reasons for the original decision and make a statement on the matter.

About 10,000 radio transmitters and transmitter receivers were dumped in this shaft. I cannot say how many were recovered, but I understand that no pieces have been removed since September, 1946, when an undertaking was given in an action in the
High Court that no further equipment would be taken from the pit, which was then closed. When it was decided to dump these sets the question was whether it would have been economical to break them down for recoverable components. It was not considered economical to do so as they were damaged military types, unsuitable for civilian use, and at that time large quantities of serviceable parts were being sold competitively to the trade. In present conditions no set would be destroyed or dumped unless it was considered advisable on security grounds or unless it had been proved that there was no market for it.

Is the Minister aware that of the so-called damaged sets, not one valve was damaged or had been removed? They were 22 valve sets. Further, is the Minister aware that there was a large number of rotary converters which have been sold at a large profit to industry in Lancashire, and that of the sets so dumped there were 8,000 complete sets which were sold at an average price of £8 or £10 a set? Is not this an extremely incompetent way of managing the country's business?

I cannot accept all these facts. All I know is that there was no new apparatus of any sort put in this shaft, that all the second-hand apparatus which was put there was found to be absolutely unsaleable, and the space where these sets previously were housed was urgently needed for other purposes.
Why were these sets not put up for sale or tender in the first place, to give somebody a chance to make the profit, which apparently has been done since?
They were found to be completely unsaleable.

In view of the very serious allegations in this case, will the Minister give an undertaking to have a full public inquiry into the matter to ascertain the true facts so that the people responsible can be brought to book?

No, Sir. I do not consider anybody is responsible for any negligence. This was about three years ago. Most careful inquiries were made to see whether this apparatus was saleable or serviceable in any way. It was
only after the most careful consideration that it was found that it was not saleable and that the best thing to do was to dump it.
Rather than sell machine tools to Poles, will the right hon. Gentleman follow this precedent and put them into a pit?

Is the Minister aware that his Ministry, or the Ministry of Fuel and Power, attempted to stop the extraction of this equipment, although the rights had been purchased by a man in that Division? Is the right hon. Gentleman aware that this was an effort by the Ministry to hush up what is nothing less than a major scandal? I have seen the sets, the valves and the rotary converters. They were new and undamaged, and they were of considerable value.
In view of this direct conflict of evidence on what obviously is a most serious allegation, will not the Minister consider referring this matter to some form of public inquiry?
No, Sir. If the hon. Member who raised the Question has some information contrary to that which I have given to the House——
He has given it.
—information which is supported by some evidence, I shall be very willing to look into the evidence and answer a further Question on the matter, if necessary.

In view of the utterly unsatisfactory nature of the reply, I wish to give notice that I shall raise this matter on the Adjournment, and I shall bring some of the machinery to the House to show to the right hon. Gentleman.

asked the Minister of Supply how many sets of radio equipment and of what type have been buried in the Delphouse pit near Cheadle, Staffordshire; and whether, in view of the profitable recovery of sets from the Wonder pit nearby, he will concert with the Minister of Fuel and Power for their extraction.

About 1,300 radio transmitters and transmitter receivers
were dumped in the Delphouse pit, and 30,000 incendiary bombs were dumped on top of them. It would, therefore, be impracticable to recover the sets, which could not in any case be used for civilian purposes.

Was the wireless trade given any opportunity to purchase these sets before they were dumped, in order to secure the component parts which are in such short supply and so urgently needed in this country and for export?
These sets, and certainly the sets mentioned in the previous Question, were offered to the trade but they were unsaleable. These sets were not suitable for civilian use.

The right hon. Gentleman said that the sets were offered, but is he aware that tenders were received in this country from Poland, Holland and France, and that they could not be taken because the sets were not put on the market?

asked the Minister of Supply why permission asked for by Bio Electrics, Ltd., to send to the hon. and gallant Member for Central Glasgow the approved specification and drawings of electric soldering irons as laid down by the Co-ordinating Committee on Hand Tools has not been granted, although asked for in July last.

This specification was a draft which was circulated to manufacturers for their comments. It was subsequently withdrawn for reconsideration and finally abandoned. While permission to send a copy to the hon. and gallant Member was not specifically refused, it was assumed that the firm would not, in these circumstances, wish to do so. If, however, he would like a copy of the draft, I shall be glad to send him one.
Is the specification which replaced the one that was withdrawn available for the use of Members, if they want it?
If there is a specification which has replaced the one which has been withdrawn, I will certainly send one to the hon. and gallant Member, if he so desires.
asked the Minister of Supply in what way a steel company may now finance an urgent approved project for which a public issue of new capital would have been made.

All the normal ways of raising new capital are still open to a steel company. The British Iron and Steel Corporation will be liable for all debts to banks or other creditors of those companies whose shares it will acquire, and subscribers to new issues of securities will receive compensation equal to the price of issue.
Does the Minister think that it is very likely the public will subscribe to those new issues?

asked the Minister of Supply whether he is aware that 250 monkeys recently arrived in this country from Calcutta by air consigned to his Department; and for what purpose he intends to use these animals.
The animals referred to are required for research purposes, the nature of which it would not be in the public interest to disclose.

In view of the extreme reticence of the Minister of Supply, like that of his right hon. Friend the First Lord of the Admiralty, may I ask whether he is aware that this reticence only leads to the view among the general public that these animals are needed for some nefarious purpose? If it is, in fact, proved that they are needed for the same reasons as the animals were needed at the Bikini trials, the conscience of this country will be as revolted as it was at that time.
In view of the shortage of Labour candidates, is it a fact that safe seats have been found for all these monkeys?
Are these animals being brought here for experiments in bacteriological warfare?

asked the Minister of Supply how many offers con stituting breaches of the Iron and Steel
Orders have been investigated by his price investigations office since 1st January, 1946; on how many occasions were proceedings instituted; and how many convictions were obtained.

Eleven offers to sell iron and steel above controlled prices have been investigated, and it has been decided not to prosecute. Nine cases are still under investigation, and I cannot say yet whether or not proceedings will be instituted.
Can the Minister say why it has been decided not to prosecute?
Because it was considered that the evidence was not strong enough to obtain a conviction.
